introduction.p:
The learning objectives for this chapter are:
To understand and be able estimate and represent relationships between explanatory variables and a response variable.
To understand and be able least-squares regression.
To understand and be able to apply the concept of correlation.

section.title: Scatter Plots
section.p: A scatter plot shows the relationship between two quanitative variable. The values of one variable are on the horizontal axis, while the values of the second variable are on the vertical axis. Each data pair is represented by a point determined by the values on each axis. In a scatter plot, we look for patterns in the data as well as deviations.

Two variables are positively associated if above average data of of one variable corresponds to above average data of the second variable. The variables are negatively associated if if above average data of of one variable corresponds to below average data of the second variable.

section.title: Correlation
section.p: Correlation describes the strength of the linear relationship between two quantitative variables. More specifically, suppose that x and y are data for n individuals. That is, we have data sets \{x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n \} and \{y_1, y_2, \ldots, y_n \}. Furthermore, suppose that \overline{x} and s_x are the mean and standard deviation for the variable x, while \overline{y} and s_y are the mean and standard deviation for the variable y. We define the correlation r between x and y to be r = \frac{1}{n - 1} \sum_{i=1}^n \left( \frac{x_i - \overline{x}}{s_x} \right) \left( \frac{y_i - \overline{y}}{s_y} \right).

section.title: Least-Squares Regression
section.p: A straight line describing how a response variable y changes as an explanatory variable changes is called a regression line. We can use a regression line to make predictions. The least-squares regression line is the straight line that minimizes the sum of the squares of vertical distances of the data points from the line. The least-squares regression line is given by the equation \hat{y} = a + bx, where the slope b is given by b = r \frac{s_y}{s_x} and the intercept is a = \overline{y} - b \overline{x}.
